text: CT chest shows bilateral ground-glass opacities predominantly in the peripheral and posterior lung fields, compatible with atypical pneumonia such as viral infection. No pleural effusion. Mild mediastinal lymphadenopathy.
Portable AP chest radiograph demonstrates right lower lobe consolidation with air bronchograms, consistent with lobar pneumonia. Cardiomediastinal silhouette within normal limits. No pneumothorax.

MRI of the knee reveals a full-thickness tear of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) with associated bone contusions of the lateral femoral condyle and posterolateral tibial plateau. Small joint effusion. Medial meniscus posterior horn shows increased signal without definite tear.

Right upper quadrant ultrasound demonstrates multiple gallstones with posterior acoustic shadowing. Gallbladder wall thickening to 4 mm and positive sonographic Murphy sign, concerning for acute cholecystitis. Common bile duct measures 5 mm without intrahepatic ductal dilation.

Non-contrast head CT shows a hyperdense acute intraparenchymal hemorrhage in the left basal ganglia measuring approximately 2.5 cm with surrounding edema and mild mass effect. No midline shift. Ventricles are normal in size.

MRI brain demonstrates multiple periventricular and juxtacortical T2/FLAIR hyperintense lesions without diffusion restriction, suggestive of demyelinating disease such as multiple sclerosis. No abnormal enhancement. Brainstem and cerebellum are unremarkable.
AP and oblique views of the left hand show a nondisplaced transverse fracture of the fifth metacarpal neck (boxer's fracture). Joint spaces are preserved. No dislocation.

Obstetric ultrasound at 20 weeks shows a single live intrauterine pregnancy in cephalic presentation. Fetal biometry consistent with gestational age. Placenta anterior without previa. Amniotic fluid index within normal range.
Contrast-enhanced CT abdomen/pelvis reveals acute uncomplicated sigmoid diverticulitis with focal bowel wall thickening and pericolic fat stranding. No abscess or free air. Appendix is normal.

MRI lumbar spine indicates L4-L5 disc desiccation with a posterior central disc protrusion contacting the ventral thecal sac and mild bilateral foraminal narrowing. No significant canal stenosis. Conus medullaris terminates at L1.
